title: Amazônia Now
html:
The discourse that the Amazon Forest is being devastated is fallacious. Today, 84% of its native vegetation is preserved.

The Amazon biome consists of the largest tropical forest on the planet, but it also houses, in its Brazilian portion, about 25 million people who cannot be forgotten.

The actions under development in the region aim to expand the potential of the bioeconomy for the production chains, providing social inclusion and sustainable productivity for local communities, increasing investments in research and development in biotechnology and exploring the existing biodiversity.

Environmental policies need to put people at the center of attention, otherwise Brazil will not overcome the paradox that the environmentally richest region sustains the worst rates of deforestation. human development in the country.

  • Overcoming this situation depends on the implementation of an Environmental Justice, guaranteeing the improvement of living conditions and prosperity for those who live there, especially for the indigenous and traditional communities.
  • it is essential to create economic alternatives that reduce the appeal of illegal activities as an unambiguous and concomitant form of repression.

Actions in the region need to contemplate five axes: land title regularization; implementation of ecological-economic zoning; promotion of the bioeconomy; increase, in volume and intensity, of payment for environmental services; and zero tolerance for illegal deforestation.

GENERAL DATA

Biome Amazon (Amazon Rainforest)

  • It occupies 49% of the Brazilian territory (4.2 million km2).
  • In addition to Brazil, the Amazon biome is present in eight other countries: Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Venezuela, Guyana, French Guiana, Peru and Suriname.
  • Altogether, the biome occupies a territory of about 8 million km 2   in South America.
  • 84% of the Amazon is untouched.
  • It has 132 federal conservation units (15% of the biome).
  • According to Forest Code , private properties are required to preserve 80% native Amazonian vegetation.
  • 3.52 million km 2 of native forest (Source: Embrapa Territorial).
  • 25% in unregistered areas;
  • 26% in private properties;
  • 49% in areas protected by law (conservation units and indigenous lands).
  • Your area and the equivalent of the 27 countries that make up the European Union   (Germany, Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Cyprus, Croatia, Denmark, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Estonia, Finland, France, Greece, Holland, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Poland, Portugal, Czech Republic, Romania and Sweden).
  • In all, Brazil protects 30% of its territory (14% of protected areas worldwide) the planet). The average protection rate for large countries is 10%.
  • Australia: 19.2%

Legal Amazon

  • Political-administrative concept instituted in 1953 with the objective of promoting the socioeconomic development of the states of the Amazon region that historically share the same economic, political and social challenges.
  • Includes 9 states: Acre, Amapá, Pa ra, Amazonas, Rondônia, Roraima, Mato Grosso, Tocantins and Maranhão.
  • Includes 3 biomes: Amazon and parts of the Cerrado and Pantanal.
  • It occupies 61% of the Brazilian territory (5.2 million km 2 ).
  • It houses 14% of the Brazilian population: 23 million people. (Source: IBGE and ONU)
  • Population density of the Legal Amazon: 6 inhabitants / km 2
  • Population density of the country: 22 inhabitants / km 2
  • 80% of the areas protected by the federal government are in the Amazon. (Source: ICMBio, Funai and Embrapa Territorial)
  • On average, 51% of the territories of the states of the Legal Amazon are protected (Source: ICMBio, Funai and Embrapa Territorial):
  • Amapá: 71%
  • Roraima: 66.7%
  • Para: 56 , 2%
  • Amazonas: 54.5%
  • Acre: 46.4%
  • Rondônia: 42.9%
  • Mato Grosso: 21.1%  

PERCEPTION OF BRAZILIAN ABOUT AMAZONIA

Research by the National Confederation of Industry (CNI), commissioned from the FSB Research Institute, in late 2020, found that:

  • 95% of Brazilians believe that it is possible, at the same time, to protect and develop the Amazon.
  • 83% believe that national development depends on the protected environment.
  • 82% of Brazilians trust the country to be able to explore the forest intelligently , preserving its natural resources.
  • 80% of Brazilians are proud of the Amazon.
  • 50% of Brazilians say they are affected by some environmental problem.
  • 59% of people say they know what sustainable development is, but of these, only 55% (28% of the total) know how to deal with the concern, at the same time, with the environment, with society in general and with the generation of jobs and income in the country.
  • 83% say that forest preservation is very important for the country's growth, as national development depends on the protected environment.

Another finding of the research was that, for most part of the ears, greater productive activity in the region will result in benefits such as reduced unemployment, greater environmental preservation, better quality of life and reduced illegal activities in the region.

Source: CNI / FSB Research Institute
